introduction.p: In Section 10.3 we represented the sum of two complex numbers graphically as a vector addition. Is there a way to visualize the product or quotient of two complex numbers? One way to explore a new idea is to consider a simple case. What happens to the vector representing a complex number when we multiply the number by i?

statement.p: Represent z=2+3i and iz=2i-3 as vectors in the complex plane.

sidebyside.p: The vectors are shown at right. We see that multiplication by i corresponds to rotating the vector around the origin by 90\degree in the counterclockwise direction.

introduction.p: The previous example suggests that multiplication by a complex number results in a rotation. Polar coordinates are well suited to processes that involve rotation, because they use angles to specify location. Thus, we will next represent complex numbers in an alternate polar form.

subsection.title: Polar Form
subsection.p: In general, we can write the real and imaginary parts of z in terms of r and \theta as a=r \cos \theta~~~~\text{and}~~~~b=r\sin \theta Thus, the complex number z=a+bi can also be written as z=(r\cos\theta)+(r\sin \theta)i, or z=r(\cos\theta+i\sin \theta).

statement.p: Find the polar form for z=\sqrt{3} + i.

sidebyside.p: Thus, z= 2(\cos \dfrac{\pi}{6} + i\sin \dfrac{\pi}{6}) The graph of z is shown at right.

assemblage.title: Polar Form for a Complex Number
assemblage.p: The complex number z=a+bi can be written in the polar form z=r(\cos\theta+i\sin \theta) where r=\sqrt{a^2+b^2} and \theta is defined by a=r \cos \theta,~~~~b=r\sin \theta,~~~~0 \le \theta \le 2\pi The angle \theta is called the argument of the complex number, and r is its length, or modulus.

statement.p: Find the polar form for w=1+i\sqrt{3}.

subsection.title: Products and Quotients in Polar Form
subsection.p: The polar form is especially convenient for computing the product or quotient of two complex numbers.

assemblage.title: Product in Polar Form
assemblage.p: If z_1=r(\cos \alpha+i\sin \alpha) and z_2=R(\cos \beta+i\sin \beta), then z_1z_2=rR(\cos (\alpha + \beta) + i \sin (\alpha + \beta))

subsection.p: This formula, which you will prove in the Homework Problems, says that the product of two complex numbers in polar form is the complex number with modulus rR and argument \alpha + \beta Thus, to find the product of two complex numbers, we multiply their lengths and add their arguments.

statement.p: Find the product of z= 2(\cos \dfrac{\pi}{6} + i\sin \dfrac{\pi}{6}) and w= 2(\cos \dfrac{\pi}{3} + i\sin \dfrac{\pi}{3}).

solution.p: We multiply the moduli, 2 \cdot 2 =4, and add the arguments, \dfrac{\pi}{6}+\dfrac{\pi}{3} = \dfrac{\pi}{2}. The polar form of the product is thus zw=4(\cos \dfrac{\pi}{2} + i\sin \dfrac{\pi}{2}) = 4i Note that z and w are the numbers from the previous example and exercise, namely z=\sqrt{3} + i and w=1+i\sqrt{3}. You can compute the product zw in Cartesian form to check that you get the same result, 4i.

sidebyside.p: The figure at right shows the graphs of z and w, and their product, zw. You can see that multiplying z by w rotates the graph of z by the argument of w, namely \dfrac{\pi}{3} or 60\degree.

subsection.p: The quotient of two complex numbers in polar form is computed in a similar fashion.

assemblage.title: Quotient in Polar Form
assemblage.p: If z_1=r(\cos \alpha+i\sin \alpha) and z_2=R(\cos \beta+i\sin \beta), then \dfrac{z_1}{z_2}=\dfrac{r}{R}(\cos (\alpha - \beta) + i \sin (\alpha - \beta))

statement.p: Find the quotient of z= 2(\cos \dfrac{\pi}{6} + i\sin \dfrac{\pi}{6}) and w= 2(\cos \dfrac{\pi}{3} + i\sin \dfrac{\pi}{3}).

solution.p: We divide the moduli, \dfrac{2}{2} = 1, and subtract the arguments, \dfrac{\pi}{6}-\dfrac{\pi}{3} = \dfrac{-\pi}{6}.

sidebyside.p: The polar form of the quotient is thus \dfrac{z}{w}=1(\cos \dfrac{-\pi}{6} + i\sin \dfrac{-\pi}{6})=\dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{2} - \dfrac{1}{2} i The figure at right shows the graphs of z,~w, and the quotient \dfrac{z}{w}.

statement.p: Compute the quotient \dfrac{z}{w} for z=3+3i and 2=-2+2i.

subsection.title: Powers and Roots of Complex Numbers
subsection.p: Because raising to a power is just repeated multiplication, we can also use the polar form to simplify powers of a complex number. For example, if z=r(\cos\alpha+i\sin \alpha), then z^2=z \cdot z = r \cdot r(\cos(\alpha+ \alpha) +i\sin (\alpha + \alpha)) We compute z^2 by squaring the modulus, r, and doubling the argument, \alpha, so the polar form is z^2= r^2(\cos 2\alpha+i\sin 2\alpha) An analogous result holds for all positive integers n, and is known as De Moivre's Theorem.

assemblage.title: De Moivre's Theorem
assemblage.p: If z=r(\cos\alpha+i\sin \alpha) is a complex number in polar form, and n is a positive integer, then z^n= r^n(\cos n\alpha+i\sin n\alpha)

statement.p: Raise z=\sqrt{3} + i to the fourth power.

subsection.p: DeMoivre's Theorem also works for fractional values of n, so we can compute roots of complex numbers. For example, by applying the theorem with n=\dfrac{1}{2}, we see that one of the square roots of z=r(\cos\alpha+i\sin \alpha) is z^{1/2}=r^{1/2}(\cos \dfrac{\alpha}{2}+i\sin \dfrac{\alpha}{2}) Now, every number,whether real or complex, has two square roots. To find the other root, remember that we can add a multiple of 2\pi to the argument of z, that is, we can also write the polar form of z as z=r(\cos(\alpha+2\pi)+i\sin (\alpha+2\pi)) The second square root of z is thus r^{1/2}(\cos (\dfrac{\alpha}{2}+\pi)+i\sin (\dfrac{\alpha}{2}+\pi)
It is not hard to show that every number has three complex cube roots, four complex fourth roots, and so on.

statement.p: Find three complex cube roots of 8.

solution.p: One polar form of z=8 is z=8(\cos 0 + i \sin 0) so one of its cube roots is z_1=8^{1/3}(\cos \dfrac{0}{3} + i \sin \dfrac{0}{3}) = 2(\cos 0 + i \sin 0) = 2 But by adding multiples of 2\pi to the argument, we can also write the polar form of as z=8(\cos 2\pi + i \sin 2\pi)~~~~\text{and}~~~~z=8(\cos 4\pi + i \sin 4\pi)

sidebyside.p: The three roots are shown at right. Note that they are evenly spaced around a circle of radius 2. You can check that adding further muliples of 2\pi to the argument does not generate any new cube roots.
